steps.title: Take an antihistamine.
steps.content: Take an antihistamine. This will lower your body’s response to any allergens and can reduce your swelling. You can find an antihistamine over-the-counter, but your doctor could also prescribe one that best fits your needs. [2] X Trustworthy Source MedlinePlus Collection of medical information sourced from the US National Library of Medicine Go to source Some antihistamines cause drowsiness, some may be fast acting, and all can be taken in different doses. For daytime use, choose an antihistamine that is labeled non-drowsy. For example, cetirizine (Zyrtec), loratadine (Claritin), and fexofenadine (Allegra) are popular non-drowsy options that also give you 24-hr relief from allergy symptoms. Be sure to follow all of the instructions on the packaging. Don’t take an antihistamine for longer than a week without talking to your doctor. It is best to talk to your doctor before taking an antihistamine.

steps.title: Apply a cool compress to the area for up to 20 mins at a time.
steps.content: Apply a cool compress to the area for up to 20 mins at a time. A cool compress, such as an ice pack, will reduce your body’s inflammatory response. This will reduce both your swelling and pain. [3] X Research source Don’t put ice up against your skin without first wrapping fabric around it. Otherwise, you could damage your skin.

steps.title: Stop taking any medication, supplement, or herb not prescribed by a doctor.
steps.content: Stop taking any medication, supplement, or herb not prescribed by a doctor. Unfortunately, these items can cause allergic reactions in some people. Even common over-the-counter medications like ibuprofen can trigger some people. [4] X Trustworthy Source MedlinePlus Collection of medical information sourced from the US National Library of Medicine Go to source Get your doctor's approval before you start taking it again.

steps.title: Use your inhaler if you have one and experience throat swelling.
steps.content: Use your inhaler if you have one and experience throat swelling. This will help open your airways. [5] X Research source However, if you have trouble breathing, then it’s important that you see the doctor immediately. Get emergency treatment if you’re having trouble breathing.

steps.title: Use an Epipen for emergency situations.
steps.content: Use an Epipen for emergency situations. The active ingredient in an Epipen is epinephrine, which is a type of adrenaline. It can help relieve the symptoms of your allergic reaction fast. [6] X Research source After you administer the medicine, visit your doctor immediately. If your doctor has not prescribed an Epipen for you, visit an emergency room, where they can administer the medication.

steps.title: Visit your doctor if your swelling persists or is severe.
steps.content: Visit your doctor if your swelling persists or is severe. Swelling that doesn’t impede your ability to breathe should respond to at-home treatment. If it doesn’t get better after a few hours or starts to get worse, you should seek medical assistance. The doctor can prescribe a stronger treatment, such as corticosteroids. [7] X Trustworthy Source DermNet NZ Online clinical resource website written and run by dermatologists providing evidence-based information about dermatology and skin health Go to source You should also see the doctor if you’ve never experienced swelling before. Seek emergency medical care if you’re having trouble breathing, have abnormal breathing sounds, or feel faint. [8] X Trustworthy Source MedlinePlus Collection of medical information sourced from the US National Library of Medicine Go to source

steps.title: Ask your doctor for an oral corticosteroid.
steps.content: Ask your doctor for an oral corticosteroid. These medications reduce inflammation in your body, which in turn reduces swelling. They’re often used after antihistamines alone have been ineffective at reducing swelling. [9] X Trustworthy Source DermNet NZ Online clinical resource website written and run by dermatologists providing evidence-based information about dermatology and skin health Go to source For example, your doctor may prescribe prednisone. Corticosteroids can have side effects, including fluid retention that can cause swelling, high blood pressure, weight gain, glaucoma, mood issues, behavioral issues, and memory problems. For a severe reaction, the doctor may administer corticosteroids via an IV. Follow all of your doctor’s instructions for taking your medication.

steps.title: Get allergy testing
steps.content: Get allergy testing to discover your triggers, if necessary. Your doctor may order allergy testing. [10] X Trustworthy Source MedlinePlus Collection of medical information sourced from the US National Library of Medicine Go to source If this occurs, you’ll visit an allergy specialist. A nurse will scratch your skin with a small amount of various allergens. They’ll then monitor your reaction to each substance to see if you are allergic. Your specialist will evaluate your test results. Based on this information, the specialist can recommend good treatment options for you, such as avoiding your triggers and possibly getting allergy shots. A single reaction, especially if it's mild, may not warrant testing or regular treatment. A severe reaction, though, or reactions that occur enough to disrupt your daily life should be tested.

steps.title: Avoid your triggers.
steps.content: Avoid your triggers. These are the things that you’re allergic to, such as foods, substances, or plants. Staying away from them is the best way to prevent the swelling that comes along with an allergic reaction. [11] X Trustworthy Source National Health Service (UK) Public healthcare system of the UK Go to source Here are some ways to do that: Check ingredients lists on foods you want to eat. Ask people about the contents of foods and drinks. Don’t take medications, supplements, or herbs without talking to your doctor. Keep your home clean and as free of allergens as possible. For example, keep dust at bay by cleaning often with a duster that traps particles. Use a HEPA air filter. Don’t go outside during peak pollen hours. Alternatively, wear a face mask. Don’t interact with animals whose dander triggers you.

steps.title: Take your medications.
steps.content: Take your medications. Your doctor may recommend taking a daily antihistamine. This could include a non-drowsy 24-hour option like cetirizine (Zyrtec) or loratadine (Claritin). In some cases, your doctor may prescribe other medications as well, such as an inhaler or corticosteroid. Take your medications as prescribed by the doctor. [12] X Trustworthy Source DermNet NZ Online clinical resource website written and run by dermatologists providing evidence-based information about dermatology and skin health Go to source If you skip your medication, then your body will be more susceptible to your triggers.

steps.title: Avoid things that aggravate swelling.
steps.content: Avoid things that aggravate swelling. This often includes getting very hot, eating spicy food, or drinking alcohol. [13] X Trustworthy Source National Health Service (UK) Public healthcare system of the UK Go to source Although they may not be the direct cause of your allergic swelling, they can make it worse or make your body more prone to swelling. Ibuprofen and ACE (angiotensin converting enzyme) inhibitors can also worsen swelling. If the doctor has prescribed one of these, talk to your doctor before stopping, as they may decide that the benefits of taking them outweigh the risk of swelling. [14] X Research source
